Key Arguments: The legislation assumes ACMA can determine absolute truth, which is unrealistic.
Truth is not always absolute and can change over time with new information.
Experts may not always provide accurate information due to biases or incomplete knowledge.
Consensus is not always a reliable indicator of truth, as history has shown with scientific breakthroughs.
There is a risk of pressure to accept false truths due to vested interests.
Truth can be subjective and influenced by satire, exaggeration, or omission.
Main Themes: Historical examples of consensus being incorrect
Potential for misuse of power and suppression of dissent
Criticism of government exemption from scrutiny
Notable Quotes: This legislation blithely believes that the ACMA will know 100% of the truth of all matters, or have access to people who will, which is a pious notion in the extreme.

If the ACMA had operated at the time and accepted the consensus view as the truth and that the dissenting views were disinformation or misinformation, the consequences for society might have been dire.
The proposed legislation is not only flawed but should be abandoned completely because the task is impossible.
